text:
Hello Superpath community!

We have a new "Dear Superpath" question. This is a way for folks to ask anonymous questions. 

Career stage: junior (1-3 years of experience)

"Hey folks, I have 3.5 years of experience in content marketing in B2B SaaS and I was recently promoted to the position of team lead. Is it too early? Should I consider going back to IC roles? 

I'm doing okay so far, but I do find that some parts of people management require more patience than I have (which is okay with me). And, as many of you have mentioned, leadership roles in content marketing are a mix of managing people + executing so I'm juggling both. 

And here's another thing to consider: I feel like I have a lot to learn when it comes to content marketing and there's a lot of room for improvement when it comes to my writing skills. So, I'm a bit confused about how this team lead role is going to impact my career. Suggestions?"

Generally speaking, I think this will only accelerate your career and give you more options in the future.

You're gonna learn tons. You'll learn a lot from the team you manage too, in terms of upping your writing skills.

Seek mentors in people management, and always keep in mind that there are rarely REAL emergencies in marketing. "Babies aren't dying," was our agency mantra whenever, you know, a client had an 11PM meltdown over a pantone colour.

text: [Relevant to in-house marketers] Anyone else feel like they get the best ideas & are more excited about work after crossing the 12-month mark at a company? I was feeling spiffy about how much context I have (now that I've spent 1.5 years at my current workplace) and how that has enabled me to prioritise better & take on bigger, more important projects at work, so I made this a while ago. Let me know what you think!

elements.text: [Relevant to in-house marketers] Anyone else feel like they get the best ideas & are more excited about work after crossing the 12-month mark at a company? I was feeling spiffy about how much context I have (now that I've spent 1.5 years at my current workplace) and how that has enabled me to prioritise better & take on bigger, more important projects at work, so I made this a while ago. Let me know what you think!

text: Yes. I know I’m an outlier, but I’ve spent 3-5 years at every company I’ve worked for. I typically feel it takes 6 months to really onboard and go beyond “low-hanging fruit” and 12 months before things start to feel locked in and moving towards mastery.

elements.text: Yes. I know I’m an outlier, but I’ve spent 3-5 years at every company I’ve worked for. I typically feel it takes 6 months to really onboard and go beyond “low-hanging fruit” and 12 months before things start to feel locked in and moving towards mastery.

text: 100%. I’ve mostly been at startups, and so it often feels like anything cool is always 6 months away, whether that’s a game changing new feature in the product or a strategic shift that will change how I do my job (e.g. getting a bigger budget!) Perhaps “Waiting it out” isn’t a good strategy if you’re working for a more established company  — they should have their sh*t together IMO — but for the startup life, patience has served me well.

text:
I feel like I could have written this question two years ago, such a weird feeling!

As a team lead myself I can say you won't spend as much time writing, that's for sure, but that doesn't mean your skills won't grow. On the contrary, you'll have to think about how to write well much more now that you have people who depend on you for feedback and inspiration. This will give you a powerful motivation to keep learning whatever you can about content marketing and writing.

If by any chance you want to talk more about this privately, my DMs are open. I'd be happy to help out.

text:
I suspect most of the leadership/manager folks in Superpath yearn to do IC work. Not everyone, but a lot more than are chiming in here.

Building processes, deliverables,  tracking budgets, setting salary bands and hiring planning…and then managing people, setting their OKRs/KPIs, shepherding their success while motivating them to do their best work on your watch…it can be exhausting, overwhelming, and unsatisfying. Sure, you might be great at 1-1s, but what do you have to show for it?

> How did you decide whether to stay IC or move into people management?  
Higher, more reliable pay. As much as I love writing, I am a mediocre writer and not much of an expert in anything to be an SME (except random topics that aren’t profitable). But people have told me they like working with me, and am a fair, natural leader, so that validated my decision and motivation to become a manager/director.
> 
> How did you know you were ready to start managing people?”
No one is ever _ready_, and if they claim to be, they’re full of shit. You can’t possibly be “ready” for the range of personalities, quirks, sensitivities, and hang-ups that individual people bring to their work. But if you’re committed to being a fair, compassionate, clear leader who’s OK with being self-less and trustworthy, being a leader isn’t that hard.

I still do lots of IC work (editing, quick rewrites, working with freelancers, paying invoices, all the unsexy editorial work that characterizes most IC tasks), but I love it. Good to keep the muscles flexed.

text: <@URAV154AV> I feel you! I feel like it's only now that I've _really_ understood the market, our customers and the goals of all the teams I work with. Plus, I know all about what has worked or what hasn't worked in the past, and what will have the biggest impact and can prioritize the same.

elements.text: I feel you! I feel like it's only now that I've

understood the market, our customers and the goals of all the teams I work with. Plus, I know all about what has worked or what hasn't worked in the past, and what will have the biggest impact and can prioritize the same.

text:
<@UJFELMVU1> I completely get your point about waiting it out for resources and features in a startup. 

However, when it comes to well established companies, I wasn't talking about waiting for resources/features, I meant waiting long enough to gain context, to understand how the business runs so you know which gears/levers to pull. That takes a while to understand IMO.

At a startup, you're starting from scratch and already have a long list of low-hanging fruits to grab so it's a bit different there. But either way, you'll gain more expertise and "mastery", as <@URAV154AV> put it, at marketing within an industry the longer you work with that startup.

put it, at marketing within an industry the longer you work with that startup.
